If you are using shared volumes with a docker container, then the storage will be available on your disk (e.g. if you are launching your container as in our quickstart guide https://qdrant.tech/documentation/quick-start/)

`on_disk` option in `vectors_config` is not about persisting, but about resource trade-offs. When `on_disk=True`, qdrant utilises memmap files instead of loading everything into memory, which can save cost on RAM

Hey, there are two important parameters here:
1. `limit` - number of results to return
2. `score_threshold` - threshold for the similarity score

`limit` defines how many results to return, and if you set `score_threshold`, Qdrant won't return points with a similarity less than the threshold, but it will always return the most relevant documents first. So, adjusting the threshold won't impact the search quality but helps you remove points under a specific score if you know they won't be any good.

There are more technical details to it, but that's the gist of it.

Good question! We do that to ensure durability and data consistency. Even though a delete may have been applied already, we cannot be sure whether it has actually persisted to disk because Qdrant may have crashed unexpectedly. We replay the last few operations on start to be 100% sure all operations are applied correctly.

content:
> 6. Yes on performance and does it impact ingestion of data. (as in does it lock writes etc during a snapshot)
In Qdrant 1.8 there may be a small performance hit for updates when a snapshot is being made.
We're actively working on improving this to make snapshotting transparent though.
You can follow some of this develoment process here: https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant/pull/3420

> 7. Can snapshot creation happen at the same time as deletion?
In Qdrant 1.8, no. In a later version: probably. See the above PR.

> 8. In the snapshots section of a collection in the Qdrant dashboard, the snapshots that are available seem to alternate between snapshots on each node when the browser page is refreshed. Is this the expected way to view all snapshots on all nodes when viewing the dashboard?
No, it only shows the snapshots of the current node.
If you're accessing multiple nodes randomly through a loadbalancer (which is the case on Qdrant Cloud) you might see snapshots of a different node each time.

> 1. Does Qdrant have the ability for users to name the snapshot that is created?
No. Though once you download the file, you can give it any name you want.

> 2. How does  Qdrant suggest snapshots be set up in an Azure cloud environment? Separate volume for snapshots, use blob storage, file share etc.
All should be fine. But the same volume is usually used. A file share may also be useful here.
Note that a file share cannot be used for the storage data of Qdrant. But for storing snapshots it should be fine.

> 3. It seems that Qdrant only has the ability create snapshots to the local file system or a drive/fileshare I attach. Is there anything available that will automatically send snapshots to cloud storage?
It will not. You can configure a snapshot path in the configuration (`config.yaml`).

> 4. I do see the snapshot when listing, but is there a snapshot status field that I can monitor during the actual snapshot? In Elasticsearch for example, their snapshots have a status field that returns "In progress" during the snapshot, and then returns "Success" once its complete. Does Qdrant have anything like that?
We don't show the process of individual snapshots when listing them. They'll only be listed there if they are done creating.

But, you can set `wait=true` when creating a snapshot. Then, the creation request will wait and only return once the process it done. The response contains the snapshot details.
See: https://qdrant.github.io/qdrant/redoc/index.html#tag/collections/operation/create_snapshot

> 5. Does the snapshot in the snapshots folder only show up once the snapshot has completed?
Yes.

In our platform, we regularly train our bots. Whenever an utterance is added or removed from a bot, we will use "scroll points" to identify the changes in utterances. We then generate embeddings for these delta utterances.
np üôÇ
thanks

We operate a platform for ChatBots. We're considering integrating QdrantDB into our system. Previously, we stored embeddings in a file system using .pkl files. With the introduction of QdrantDB, embeddings for newly trained bots will be stored directly in QdrantDB. For existing bots, their embeddings remain in the file system. When a search request is made, we first check if the vectors are available in the QdrantDB collection using "scroll points". If they are not found, we fall back to using the vectors stored in the file system. It's important for us to maintain backward compatibility in our platform, which is why we verify the presence of the payload index in the collection by using "scroll points".

content: Hi, could you please share a full collection info? I can't find the number of vectors, and number of indexed vectors, as well as some other attributes in your output

Applying filters cause performance degradation
We use Qdrant in production. It performed good enough. In last update we decided to use filters to filter out old vectors in search result. It cause a degradation in Qdrant performance. Response time‚Äôs increased from 8ms up to 4s through several hours after filters were applied.

Hey

It seems like you haven't yet experimented that much with with the project, so first suggestion is to keep it simple

If you are using a multilingual model - why do you need translations to several languages for the same items? I would suggest to keep it simple: leave only one language, e.g. english, if you have it, and work with it.

I would probably start with joining columns into a string, maybe augmenting it like "Title: {title}, brand: {brand}, color: {color}". However, I am not sure about viability of this approach, because vector search might not handle the conditions that good. (You might want to try out hybrid search here (dense vectors + sparse vectors), and use SPLADE models (be careful with the licence and find the proper model, e.g. you can use fastembed for it). It seems like you have some requirements from the client, maybe you could use payload filters as well? So, users could click some checkboxes (e.g. to choose brand) and then write their queries.

As you said, you would not be able to set  different weights to different characteristics of the item (like category or color). Moreover, Qdrant does not have such a functionality even for multiple vectors and if you really want it, you will need to implement it on your side.

Btw, if you want to add these weights, how would you assign the weights? Which characteristic are more important?

Regarding query-tokenization: you can try it out and combine with filtering by payload, however I am not sure how good it will work. It can both work and not, e.g. it depends on what a typical query look like, how you would handle mistakes in queries, etc.

Regarding the collection size:
Qdrant easily handles 1M points and does not require a lot of resources for it.
We want to test how quantization on the collection impacts the quality of our application. So we want to create multiple collections with the same payload and different quantization parameters
Also can you describe more the use case about duplicating the collection?
